Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platforms, into one of two categories: threat or non-threat. Threatening someone means implying that someone will be hurt even if they do not do something specific.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: He should be executed, not given 48 years.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a violent threat to someone.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Opening up people of a different race to violent acts including death by idiots, by inciting her followers to violence, is offensive. If anything happens to the Jones family, Dembroski should be charged as an accessory.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but is not a threat to anyone.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: "who do you think should do the killing?"

Anyone and everyone. This is a community problem, so everyone who wants to be part of the solution should be allowed to help. As I said above: remove all protections on free ranging cats, and allow people to help. People who allow their pets to roam outside are part of the problem, because their pets are part of the problem. It would be very sad if pets were killed, but ultimately it is the owner's responsibility to make sure their pets are not out killing birds.

Years ago some Vermont acquaintances got one warning from the Ranger: Next time I see your dog running deer, I'll shoot it. Next time she saw it running deer, she did. 

Vermont does not pretend that trapping, neutering, and releasing dogs solves any problems. They are serious about threats. We just want to feel good about ourselves. If we were serious about feral cats, we would kill them. Neutered cats eat birds. Don't release them. Kill them.

Comment: No, James

1.  The solubility of the compound CaF prevents it from existing in water..  

2. Fluoride is an atom of the element fluorine.  Hydrofluorosilic  acid is a compound which contains F.  An atom is not a compound.

3. There is no "industrial waste" or "fertilizer factory chimney scrubber", involved in fluoridation.

4.  Relative toxicities of substances refer to amount needed to reach toxicity.  They are irrelevant when proper amounts are utilized.  Caffeine is more toxic than arsenic under relative concentrations. 

5. "Pharmaceutical grade" fluoride is produced for single use applications, not for large volumes in water systems.  While levels of arsenic and other contaminants in "pharmaceutical grade" fluoride are acceptable for single use applications, they could very well lead to greater levels of these contaminants than has HFA, if used in fluoridation.

6.  Both HFA and CaF are compounds containing fluoride ions. Neither come from smokestacks.

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: motleycrew: Thanks! Good catch. I was paraphrasing.

The actual proposed language in SB 1553 B-Engrossed would have amended ORS 163.165 to read: "(1) A person commits the crime of assault in the third degree if the person: … (d) With criminal negligence causes serious physical injury to another who is a vulnerable
user of a public way, as defined in ORS 801.608, by means of a motor vehicle; …"

And I am not a lawyer, but it looks like the ORS 161.085(10) definition of "criminal negligence."

Of course, insofar as the bill didn't pass, the legal fine points are all moot.

As I have commented previously to TIYPS, a case that prompted the law was when a driver in the Portland area drove between two bicyclists ahead who were waiting to make a left turn, and severed the leg of one bicyclist.  SB 1553 would have made such an action a crime of assault in the third degree.

Comment: I suppose a 25% holding in resources, including diamonds, lithium, gold, silver and marijuana is high but even if they halve in value, I'm still streets ahead, all else being equal. And why wouldn't an "expert" have glommed onto these things a year ago (as he doesn't appear to have done), when clearly they had nowhere to go but up?
Your point 2) baffles, because I am comparing my results to about the same period as in the article. Sure, I shouldn't expect anything like it to continue but that's another matter altogether. I'll stick to my 14% goal though, at least for 2017.
My investing philosophy is simple: I envisage the scenario of a severe downturn and allocate my portfolio as: 65% in companies that I am confident would still be around afterward; 25% in companies I'm reasonably sure would survive (including some resource firms, such as diamonds), and 10% who would be at risk but look a "good bet" for now.

Comment: Part 2.  

The School Board members were viewed as an extension of the Church Board and represented the church's interests and concerns and support of the school.  School events and calendar items were designed to include the church family - because it was their school - and never would programs/events/etc. be planned that would detract from or compete with the church.  

By and large, the church has continued to support our schools and Adventist education.  Most churches that either sponsor a school or a part of a constituency routinely invest well over 70% of their local income in their school - counting subsidies, infrastructure, programs, worthy-student, etc. - so much so that many churches have to consider the school their only or at least major form of evangelism - because there is no money left for anything else.

But, increasingly, the support is not reciprocated by the school.

Comment: Parallels exist between Alaska's budget crisis and the similar crisis in the Federal budget. The Administration's proposed cuts in Federal programs (the NEA, Public Radio etc.) resemble calls in Alaska to cut more in State government. Nationally, we have massive debt and annual spending deficits that just continue to grow. Sound familiar? These proposed cuts in the Federal budget amount to peanuts. In Alaska, credible sources estimate that firing every State employee tomorrow would save about 750 million a year. The State would still have a deficit of what, 3 billion? Of course it's fantasy to even consider such a construct - no troopers, no highway maintenance, no public services at all. Get real.

On both the State and federal level, where is the real money that contributes the most to debt and budget deficits? Nationally, that big money is in defense, interest on the debt and entitlement programs. In Alaska, after eliminating State government, where is the big money to pay the 3B?

Comment: One limitation of CC&Rs is that they do not pertain to external boundaries. For example, multistory buildings might be built adjacent to a neighborhood subject to a CC&R so that some houses can become adversely impacted. As you point out, CC&Rs can be challenged where neighborhoods have not enforced them. A lesson here is that neighborhoods should periodically educate their residents about their CC&Rs and work to have zoning laws adopted that are consistent with them.

Comment: Why do you think "let no man put asunder" is "line-drawing"?  Granted, it can be seen as line drawing.  But not if the Gospel is taken as a whole.  The people of his day -- in particular the Pharisees -- were all about drawing lines and  satisfying the requirements of the law.  Why follow in their footsteps?  Jesus was not about giving the keys to the kingdom to those who followed the law, and then lording it over sinners.  Luke 11:46.  Jesus was about something radically different.   Turning people in a different direction -- beyond the habits of the law -- was very difficult, and remains so.  A change of direction does not often come from logical argument imposed from the outside.  It must come from within.  Jesus used every mode of communication at his disposal to jar the law-based mind sets of his listeners.  "If your eye causes you to sin, pluck it out."  Without using these precise words he also said, "if line-drawing causes you to hinder metanoia by a sinner, pluck it out."

Comment: The most effective community tool for public examination of an educational budget was the Budget Review Team process introduced by Bob Crystal (20 years ago, lol?) and maintained when useful by Carol Comeau for a decade. The process resulted in hundreds of people getting their hands dirty actually working the budgets with district staff. It was messy and at times adversarial, but most of the "fat" was identified (and unfortunately in many cases, trimmed).  More importantly, however, the general public received a more granular and comprehensive understanding of the budget and the budgetary process. Amazingly enough, ideologues got less traction then.

It is high time we brought the BRT system back in Anchorage (are you listening Mr. Donnelly and Mr. Holleman) and promoted budget comprehension locally and statewide (as opposed to leaving that to non-profits masquerading as adult education programs more interested in manufacturing hysteria than in rational discussion.

Comment: Twelve years ago, federal and state officials and some of California’s largest water agencies rejected concerns that the massive earthen spillway at Oroville Dam — at risk of collapse Sunday night and prompting the evacuation of 185,000 people — could erode during heavy winter rains and cause a catastrophe.  Three environmental groups — the Friends of the River, the Sierra Club and the South Yuba Citizens League — filed a motion with the federal government on Oct. 17, 2005, as part of Oroville Dam’s relicensing process, urging federal officials to require that the dam’s emergency spillway be armored with concrete, rather than remain as an earthen hillside.

Comment: Well I don't blame lack of Christian values or lack of stable families, I blame lack of transmitting the value of education by parents to children, which can occur for many reasons, some correlated to lack of stable families.

The most important factor in school success in fact is size of vocabulary at the start of school. 

If parents are too preoccupied with their problematic love lives, or lack the cultural capital themselves, to make sure the kids get an early, good grounding in language skills, the kids will struggle in school, fall behind in reading, probably develop a hatred of it, etc.. It then becomes very difficult to catch up.

If you can barely graduate from high school, that makes attaining a university education pretty much moot, no matter how cheap.

The problem isn't getting everyone a university education, it is making sure there are decent alternatives for people who can't get one.

Comment: By the way, note how Transcanada has taken the opposite approach to KM in dealing with provincial jurisdiction.  Instead of refusing to share information with Quebec, they've actually agreed to undergo a provincial environmental assessment even though they're not legally required to do so.  That's a smart thing to do.  It will reassure moderates in the public that environmental concerns are being seriously addressed.  More importantly, it will allow the Quebec Liberals to raise specific concerns and mediate risk so that they can agree to the project on objective grounds, and that undermines the "principled" objections of their political adversaries in the PQ that this is being imposed on Quebec without consultation.  The result for Transcanada is they reduce their risk of their project becoming the nexus of a political war with a coalition of adversaries like KM's project has in BC.

Comment: Of course there is no compelling reason why we need a Canada Infrastructure Bank, but the analysis is Azfar Ali Khan and Randall Bartlett is absolute nonsense based on the usual gibberish of the left.
First, the analysis of Canada's net debt to GDP.  In measuring net debt the federal government includes the value of CPP, QPP and other pension plans as assets to offset liabilities.  Since the assets of the pension plans belong to the contributors, it is fraudulent (if the government was a private corporation) to include these asset as their own. 
Second, governments use private sector to fund projects  at higher interest rates to shift the risk to the private sector.  Ontario  has saved millions using alternative financing. (e.g. Oakville hospital built on time and on budget, Metorlinx funding Burlington GO station; years late and  40% over budget).
Borrowing to build infrastructure is not a balance sheet activity.  These people need to take economics 101.

Comment: You are incorrect. Life without parole is not available in juvenile court. It could only be applied in adult court. So the Supreme Court's decision applied to juveniles who had been charged in adult court.  Over the past several years, courts have debated whether the decision is retroactive and it has been agreed that the decision is retroactive. Many defendants who faced LWOP sentences for crimes committed when they were under 18 have gone back to court to be re-sentenced in accord with these decisions. All of these defendants have been charged in adult court and face adult penalties.

Comment: In regards to hospice care: It is explained to patients and families by all hospice agencies how they will treat a patient at end of life. Hospice is not their to prolong life or prevent death. If you want to live longer and want everything done to keep you alive, then do not sign up for hospice.  We call hospice in when a patient is showing signs that they are nearing the end of life. Most calls are made when we see failure to thrive, repeated UTI's or infections that do not respond to antibiotics, weight loss from poor appetite, multiple complex medical issues, end stages heart failure, cancer, end stages dementia, COPD, kidney failure, etc.  If your wanting comfort at end of life, you have the option of not taking life prolonging medications, such as heart medications, insulin, dialysis, or any other life sustaining treatments. They will add pain medications and other meds to help keep you comfortable to prevent suffering. Facilities do not make money off of hospice patients meds.

Comment: The idea that the test scores are the only measure of a schools effectiveness is laughable.  For as soon as you ask why school sports have no testing standards, although the use a large part of the school budget,  you find out how there are different standards for sports that do not include written test.  

A long time ago some schools tried evaluating the students by how well those students did in the world after graduation.  They were concerned with how many graduates were active voters, held jobs, volunteered  in the community, served in the military and had log term marriages.  But the staunch advocates for test results soon rejected those as not important and made the emphases on standardized test the gold mark of excellence. 

I still judge schools as I read the stories of those graduates whose lives reflect the non-tested values we use to consider as citizenship attributes: vote, hold office, volunteer, and give back to the community.

Comment: Ms Ngwenya does not actually argue that Helen Zille's attitude towards colonialism is correct, and it is unfair to her to conclude that this is her belief. I think it is a pity that she did not take on Helen Zille's statements about colonialism which are indeed, absurd and insulting. Colonialism was not a "civilising mission". Colonialism is a system through which one country, usually violently, takes political control over the resources and labour of an external region. Specialised medicine and piped water are technologies, and certainly do not require violent subjugation of a population in order for them to be adopted and developed. Democracy, a free press, and an independent judiciary in Africa have only ever been achieved (to the extent that they have) as a result of anti-colonial struggles. We have nothing to thank colonialism for except our solidarity in the continued fight against it.

Comment: The concept of reducing the fallout from automation related job loss through UBI is flawed --but we do need a new social contract.

Putting a roof over your head and food in your mouth is surviving – not living.  People need meaningful work to have a complete life.  Without it, low self-esteem is certain to follow, leading to depression and/or anti-social behaviour – as well as multi-generational families who have no idea of how to take care of themselves.  Ultimately, a UBI will expand the rich/poor gap rather than close it, since we will have a large underclass living at the subsistence level and a wealthy upper class of knowledge workers – with nothing in between.

Last time automation threatened to put huge numbers of people out of work, we went from a 6 day week to a 5 day week, and real wages rose.  Rather than a UBI, we should be looking at how we can increase leisure time with no loss in wages.

Comment: The ability to pay continually higher dividends is dependent upon growth regardless of what the market values the share at.  Dividends don't grow (or shrink) because the share price.  The dividend grows (or shrinks) based on the company's ability to pay.  Which is a direct consequence of  the company's cash flow increase or decrease, after capital requirements.

Waiting on the sidelines for a 40 - 50% price drop on most dividend growth stocks is a good way to ensure that your capital is rarely working.

I don't own McCormick but agree with John H that the stock definitely makes sense for someone looking for a long term conservative dividend growth investment.

Comment: The short version is that if it were considered an act of war, then there would be no liability. 

The civil case from the US was won based on Khadr's presence (not necessarily actions) being an 'act of terrorism' under the US Anti-Terrorism Act (ATA), which is similar to the Canadian Justice for Victims of Terrorism act (JVT)

So even if the GITMO murder conviction is eventually expunged, and that would seem likely, and perhaps even justified; there is ample evidence to uphold the civil judgment.  

The Ontario court's job at the moment is to evaluate whether Khadr's settlement funds and/or other assets should be frozen until the Ontario court can judge whether the civil case can be enforced in Ontario. 

Contrary to popular belief, the Ontario court's job is not to relitigate the civil suit.

Comment: Rik
.
If you believe your community is billing you for utilities you don’t  desire, you should address that with the billing department of the utilities division.  Because you have a beef about your water bill doesn’t mean anyone is forcing you to drink water you choose not to drink, or that anyone is preventing you from seeking water from wherever you choose.
.
Fluoridation simply adjusts the concentration of existing fluoride in public water systems to the level where maximum disease prevention occurs in those served by that system, with no adverse effects.  Fluoride is colorless, odorless, and tasteless.  There is no valid reason to fear consuming fluoridated water.  Those with an irrational phobia about fluoride in their water are certainly free to obtain their own water from wherever they choose.  However any inconvenience and expense involved in placating such phobias are the responsibility of those persons, not of society.
.
Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: Expand Federal Estate Recovery and Liens to all uninsured who are a non-payer when receiving medical care. 
-
Medicaid's Power to Recoup Benefits Paid: Estate Recovery and Liens

Under Medicaid law, following the death of the Medicaid recipient a state must attempt to recover from his or her estate whatever long-term care benefits it paid for the recipient's care. States also have the option of recovering all Medicaid benefits from individuals over age 55, including costs for any medical care, not just long-term care benefits ... 

...Once a lien is placed on the property, if the property is sold while the Medicaid beneficiary is living, not only will the beneficiary cease to be eligible for Medicaid due to the cash from the sale, but the beneficiary would have to satisfy the lien by paying back the state for its coverage of care to date... 

Read more:
https://www.elderlawanswers.com/medicaids-power-to-recoup-benefits-paid-estate-recovery-and-liens-12018

The fastest growth in population is south of the Fraser.  Families are choosing South Surrey, Langley, Aldergrove, Abbotsford, and Chilliwack, in their search for affordable housing.  Many of these areas have little to no viable public transit.

It is almost as if we want those cars - and their toll revenue - to keep rolling in.

Comment: I live in Ottawa with my husband, two year old, and we're expecting our second child. In our downtown neighbourhood, a spot in a licenced daycare costs just under $2 K per month for a child under 3. My husband and I both work full time and don't have family help with childcare. We don't go on vacation (we don't have the money or the vacation days), and we definitely don't have the latest iPhones. 

We're lucky - we were debt free out of university so we've been able to focus on building our careers and family. Still, we are seriously considering whether it makes sense for me to continue to work while our kids are young and daycare is so expensive. However, we'll need my future income to save for retirement, and after a few years out of the work force it would be hard to get a decent job. 

We no longer live in a reality of a single working parent household where the marginal costs of an additional child are low.

Comment: One of the big problems for the Crown is that most of their lawyers leave. A criminal law lawyer will either go into a larger firm or work for the Crown. I've seen court appearances move because the Crown lawyer did not show up.  The Crown is short staffed , seriously short. 
An example. Here in Cornwall, for years( 70&80's) there was a Crown lawyer who had a lethal prosecution record. If you had to go up against him you were in trouble. He was so good that by the late 80's he went on his own and is now the top criminal lawyer in Eastern Ontario. The good one's don't stay with the Crown. Therein is a big part of the problem with regards to delays.

Comment: Canada can buy any other plane it wants but the fact remains that 5 F 35s will kill all the other planes that Canada intends to buy.  This is a major fact. No matter how much people criticize F-35s problems or that it is single engine, etc.  You only need a few F 35s to kill several 4G planes.  Per plane cost comparisons are utterly foolish. In fact, 5G planes require different set of thinking including how people analyze their costs.  The F-35 acquisition, done right, may save Canada money.  You need fewer F-35s to achieve same objectives compared to many more F-18s.  Two engines also add higher maintenance costs and increase operating costs.  The F-35 engine is due for a major upgrade in 2020.  The new engine will increase efficiency by about 15% and reduce thermal signature of the aircraft making it even more stealthy.  The word "under development" should not concern anyone because list of expectations about the F-35 keeps on growing.

Comment: The owner's comments don't make a whole lot of sense. There is a lesson here, as more people travel into brown bear habitat stress on the bears will increase and so the incidents.

"L" as in loser

Comment: I dislike bickering, but your news is older. In the first place, a crescent of bone was removed through the incision to allow access to the dura with instruments. The dura was cut and the hematoma was removed and biopsied, revealing glioblastoma. It's not reasonable that doctors didn't first suspect glioblastoma from imaging, hence the removal of tissue and biopsy. News reports at the beginning of this week said the cancer was removed. This is the first step in treatment of glioblastoma, followed by radiation and chemotherapy. McCain was not "sewn up and sent home", his glioblastoma was excised, the cranial plug replaced, and the incision sewed up. This is all in the NYTimes as of this week. If you think the brain surgeon didn't suspect the most common and aggressive cancer, I think you have misled yourself. A subdural hematoma alone typically is caused by a blow to the head.

Comment: One wonders how hard he fights, and what measures he'd be willing to take to keep terrorists out of refugee camps in the middle east?

I say that not to be snarky (honest), but to raise the point of just how tricky this issue is.  The simple truth remains that the US has the largest annual legal immigration totals in the world.  That suggests a rather "generous" country in many ways.  So perhaps THAT should be a more fundamental question here: what IS the right level for immigration in the US, and why?

The ban is NOT against all Muslims, nor all countries.  We can (and often do) debate the wisdom and politics of it all, but the simple truth is that a ban like this reflects the fears of the people who live here.  Telling people not to f ear just doesn't work.  You can't mandate something like that.  Of MUCH more significance, is that despite the noise, this "ban" is relatively short term.  So perhaps energy would be better spent on getting to the underlying issues and fears?

Comment: Sen. Pete Kelly is wrong (again) about the economic impact of wildlife-viewing in Alaska, which according to a June 2014 Alaska Department of Fish and Game report (http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/index.cfm?adfg=ongoingissues.economicstudy) brings significantly more spending in Alaska than hunting. According to the report, residents and visitors spent $3.4 billion (with a B) on wildlife-viewing and hunting activities in Alaska during 2011. Of that total, nearly two-thirds of it was spent on wildlife-viewing ($2.186 billion to $1.215 billion). That means finding a balance between non-hunting and hunting is important to protect Alaska's economy. Here is a link to the summary report for the study, which has the breakdown and other info, http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/static/home/news/ongoingissues/pdfs/the-economic-importance-of-alaskas-wildlife-in-2011-summary-report.pdf, and a link to the ADF&G magazine article, http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/index.cfm?adfg=wildlifenews.view_article&articles_id=664

Comment: With regards to Quebec, it is interesting to note that Quebec actually now has a higher employment rate than Ontario.

To the best of my knowledge that is the first time this has happened since Stats. Can. started gathering modern labour force data in 1976.

Note that a person can be "employed", "unemployed" or "neither employed or unemployed" with the last group being retirees, stay-at-home parents, students who aren't working or people who otherwise aren't looking for work.  Quebec has historically had much lower labour force participation than Ontario so even when their unemployment rate looked good their employment rate was weak.

Today Quebec's labour force participation has been almost unchanged since ~2002 at around 65% while Ontario's has dropped from a high of 68.7% in late 2003/early 2004 down to 64.8% today.

Comment: That was a good read.   It shows we have to careful to link a particular factor, (like owning shares or not owning shares), as having a causal effect on voting patterns.     I was surprised the preferences were as close as they were.   

Stock ownership is hardly an even playing field.   It's one thing to 'let it ride' in a retirement account hoping for modest retirement support.   It's quite another to have the extra income that gives you management/investment advice with the goal of creating wealth.   As in most things, wealth  increases your opportunites of success through mulitiple support structures, and this would include stock investment. 

I don't see any tax policy that changes that basic dynamic.   Government programs are hopefully designed to provide greater opportunity for those who would have very little otherwise.    It's why we've come to associate great wealth with 'privilage'.    Inequality of opportunity is a fact, not a statement of ideology.

Comment: While I am glad that the Libs are acknowledging the problem and taking some steps, this doesn’t go anywhere near far enough.

When my two children were small,  I was paying roughly double my mortgage in monthly child care fees.  Luckily my spouse’s income was higher than that, but many women simply cannot afford to work because of fees – and many families are limiting the number of children they have because of cost.

Québec’s model is likely too extreme – universal care at seven bucks a day – but a means tested sliding fee scale that takes regional living costs into account would make incredible sense.  If that is too hard to administer, try making the tax deduction fairer.  In my day it was capped at 7K, and only the lower income earner could declare it.  Ridiculous.

We have two choices – help Canadian families or increase immigration levels.  I have no problems with immigrants, but feel the former is the better alternative.

Comment: I saw a comment on here to the effect of "why are we teaching a dying language when some people can't even speak English properly?"  My response is that learning a second language — any language — improves a person's use of all the languages he or she knows, and it also improves brain function and increases intelligence.  When I learned Spanish in high school and continued with it at UAF, my grasp of English grammar was highly sharpened.  I've seen the same effect in others I know when they learned a second language.  I don't speak the native language of my ancestors, which is Irish, but I know some words and phrases, and it's opened a whole new door of understanding to me.  In that language, pronouns and prepositions are sometimes combined into a single word, and it's a whole new way of understanding relationships.  The Irish phrase for "hello" literally means "god at you", which is rather trippy when you think about it.  What wonders do Alaska native languages have to offer us?

Comment: It amazes me how much attention PERS still gets. The proposal here is most likely illegal. You can't unilaterally and retroactively change the retirement plans under which people were hired and under which they worked most of their lives. You can change the plan for future hires, but the plans have been changed so dramatically over the last 20 years that the change would not have much impact. PERS is a distraction, a red herring. Benefits have been reduced over 20 times since 1995. The Court has allowed legal reductions. It has been utterly consistent about unilateral retroactive takings. The legislature may send out another illegal proposal the way they did last year, for political purposes, but it will have the same result: a waste of time, a diversion from the real tax and budget issues faced by the state, and--if it's like last time--a waste of a great amount of money and an intensified financial burden on state agencies. 

Oregon needs tax and revenue restructuring.

Comment: You've nailed it  Chris, price does matter. Cost of production/infrastructure (with the AK LNG pipe one of the highest in the world) does matter. At current Henry Hub price (2016 average $2.18 per Million BTU) the project is uneconomic and a money loser, which explains why the Big 3+ aren't interested. They  have other projects around the world with lower development costs and greater outputs, hence, they are profitable and moving to development stage. The price of natural gas is becoming decoupled from the formula of basing the LNG price on crude due to greater outputs and market forces. Consumer states such as Japan,South Korea,China India and Taiwan are all slowing their LNG imports and some are not even accepting their contracted LNG at fixed prices because its cheaper to buy on the spot (JKM) market. Couple that with numerous gas pipelines either being proposed or already under construction and it soon becomes apparent that that is no profit to be made with Alaska LNG at his time.

Comment: Let's turn the tables for a moment.  Suppose you have standing to be a plaintiff in a case that restricts abortion. You go to the ACLU- who is in the business of civil rights litigation- and demand they represent you in a case that, if upheld, will restrict abortion.

Would they take your case?

Of course not. It conflicts with their beliefs. So why is this different for a baker?  Well, because as a plaintiff you have more than an arm's length transaction. You will probably deposit a retainer. You will sign a representation agreement. And so on.

You would be a CLIENT. Businesses refuse clients all the time. By taking a deposit for a specific cake for a specific customer for a specific ceremony for a specific day, the baker is taking on a CLIENT. That is materially different than a customer pulling a cupcake off the shelf.

I hope the courts are able to make this distinction.

Comment: Outstanding response, Tio. People can always find something on the Internet to back their claim, no matter how crazy, but to definitively call into question their source is a masterpiece.

I have had one pit bull in my life, and for only a short time. While staying in Hohenwald, TN, one appeared at the house one day. She was still a puppy, maybe 4 or 5 months old, and she looked for all the world like a Holocaust survivor. Skin and bones does not do it justice, this dog had been STARVED. She crawled to me on her belly, her tail wagging furiously, desperate hope in her eyes. I fed her a package of Oscar Meyer weiners one after the other in small bites, and I cried my eyes out (crying now remembering). I kept her for a month and she blossomed into a healthy and happy and wonderful dog.

But Hohenwald, like so many towns, will not allow Pit Bulls in the city limits. Luckily a friend of the family had a farm outside town, and it did not take much convincing to find Gracie a home. =)

Violent crime has been on a downward trend in North America for ages, and that's with record high firearms sales.

Comment: Stats show immigrants, on balance, commit fewer crimes than natural born citizens. Still this new executive order is within the bounds of what Trump promised, what many Americans had sought, and - in theory at least - what passes for muster here in Canada. Bill C-24, you'll remember, was Harper's response to a growing public view that it should be easier to deport non-citizens and strip dual nationals of their Canadian citizenship if they commit serious (mostly terror related) crimes. The Liberals were intent on repealing it but, instead, have used it more frequently than the Conservatives. 

Whether this new plan proves reasonable will be determined more in the application than the theory. Enforcement often falls short of the legal capacity to deal harshly with immigrants who violate community standards. What the U.S. and Western European experience demonstrates is that it's far easier and better to prevent abuse of the system than to unwind it after the fact.

Comment: In a free society such as ours, the burden of proof for imposing restrictions lies with the person or agency imposing the restrictions. The President does not and should not have the power to randomly ban travel from any country that he chooses...this is not a dictatorship. Yet, anyway. If you need more information, look it up. And if you need more information about previous US experience with prejudicial travel and immigration bans that affected many local families, look up Yellow Peril.

Comment: It is time to draw a sharper distinction between conservatives (i.e. centrist and Red Tories that have given the lead to the Conservative Party under its various names over most of the past 150 years) and reactionaries (i.e. hardline ideologues).  

Canada's 3 major Federal Parties are each a big and broad tent of contending factions that have enough in common to compose their differences constructively in order to seek and win office and each of these Parties can be the political home of some hardline ideological elements.  However, the unity, coherence,  broad public appeal and even the continuing viability as a major Party depends on the capacity of its moderate, inclusive elements to dominate in the setting of the Party's tone and substance.

The reactionaries currently threaten to dominate the tone, substance and   leadership of the Conservative Party and it falls to the real conservatives to rally and reassert their primacy in Party affairs and not pretend that the all is well.

Comment: There have been higher incidences of allergies (asthma, eczema and food allergies) in the post-war West.  Epidemiologists who compared the people from West Germany vs. those from East Germany prior to the fall of the Berlin Wall, or those living in Hong Kong vs. those living in Mainland China, found that there are higher incidences of allergies among those populations who live a Western lifestyle.   The "cleaner" environments where kids are brought up may contribute to this.   This has been reported in scientific journals such as Nature:

http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v479/n7374_supp/full/479S2a.html

Comment: Agreed, humans did not cause the last ice age.  Ice ages are artifacts of Milankovitch cycles - subtle variations in earth's tilt, distance from the sun, solar intensity, etc. that have well known periods of occurrence (though all of them are different so their combined effects don't show up like clockwork as you might expect).  Why do you refuse to acknowledge these facts: 

-The earth has never warmed up this fast in at least the last 800,000 years.  

-There is less than 1 chance in a million that global temps and CO2 concentrations are NOT causally linked.  

-The earth's CO2 concentration is the highest it has ever been in 800,000 years (and quite possibly more) and during that time it has never spiked so high so quickly - not even close.

-Much smaller historic changes in CO2/temps have resulted in the earth going into and out of ice ages.

So where are we headed now???  Hint: It isn't going to be good...

In a World of rampant overconsumption of Earth's living lungs, pollution ravages the globe. We must stand against the spoils of greed, and allow the intact mature forest that remains BE wild and free as it is. To self-thin as it may. 
A healthy forest is one without roads and chainsaws. With snags, fallen trees and yes, the occasional fire. 

The Goose project is the watershed near the headwaters to the crystal clear spring-fed McKenzie River, Eugene's water supply. 

This is an issue of water, climate, ecosystem health and the right of the Wild to be free.

Everyone has the ability to track their symptoms and outcomes, but how many keep detailed notes of their appointments and their treatments?

Comment: I personally know of a number of cases that can't move forward because the state hasn't turned over discovery that it's mandated by law to automatically provide to the defense.   Having said that, the primary reason for delays is the sheer number of cases.  It would literally be impossible to go to trial on every criminal case. Judges live in fear that defense attorneys are going to start demanding the swift trial to which their clients are entitled, because the system would end up having to set them free due to the inability to comply with that requirement.

Comment: As a former Protestant, I've been a part of 10 different denominations spanning over 28 years -- and NO other Church I've experienced has elevated BOTH maleness and femaleness, in their respective fullness, to the extent the Catholic Church has done.   Many are confusing "equality" with "symmetry" -- as if the only way the dignity and equality of women can be fulfilled is to ensure exact symmetry of roles within the Church.   And yet, there more women saints honored in the church calendar than I can count on two hands, and there are at least four women honored as "Doctors of The Church" -- all whom have made significant contributions to our understanding of theology, the works of mercy,  and evangelism in the Church (not to mention Mary herself).  If there are any doubts about the Church's honoring the contribution of women, Read St. John Paul's "Letter to Women"  (for the  Fourth World Conference on Women in 1995)

Comment: Ridiculous post. Entire BOOKS have been written about the rich culture, the self-sustaining way of life, the fascinating mythology of the west coast peoples.  If these people "HAD no culture" then gosh, why did those good Anglican and Catholic churchmen go to so much trouble to stamp it out? Even AFTER the small-pox and the liquor ravaged their way of life.  

They didn't have plows--because this society was not agrarian.  Simple as that.  People who live hand-to-mouth don't stop to carve and raise intricate totem poles to celebrate their families and their mythology they took the time to create, or to construct substantial communal houses against the weather, or go to the trouble to stage elaborate gift-giving potlatch ceremonies. They don't  weave baskets, create ornaments,  make their own clothes--including hats. Carve seaworthy canoes.  

But your ridiculous post is very instructive, Goober.  
Man, Canada's got a long way to go...
